UA doesn't accept excuses - if you are results driven this place will be your dream.
cons: UA is moving so fast and in so many directions it can be disconcerting if you are easily distracted.  The culture here is somewhat unforgiving - your personal and professional credibility are highly emphasized, and if you take enough hits you will not recover.

pros: Great location, busy most days, on slower time periods there is adequate amounts of time to catch up on things and spot fill. The discount is very helpful, since you're required to wear 100% UA.
cons: The sales team is seen as the golden children of the whole team. They get better perks, better pay, and they're treated like (almost) royalty when most of us in the back don't get much to our name. We do more work and most of us do feel like we deserve at least an adequate pay that reflects our work. We are understaffed in back of house while the sales team gets at least 4 new people every so often. Management itself is very shaky after a great manager got relocated to a west coast UA. It's basically unfair because we do so much and get paid so little as opposed to the sales team.

review_title: Dont view the call center as an entry level position.....
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Baltimore, MD
pros: Discount on UA products, I guess. Every once in awhile, they make something worth buying.
cons:
Call Center is its on island that the rest of the company chooses not to see or care about. Very hard to get promoted from the call center, as the rest of the company looks down on the employees there. 

Pay is just enough to get you back to work. Make sure you have good rapport with your parents, you may have to move back there. 

Communication is absolutely horrible, and Im pretty sure, "diversity" is just a term to be thrown around at the Townhall meetings.  The Call Center is also very click-ish.

If you think you can use the call center as an entry spot to get into another role, you will be sadly mistaken. 

Customers are some of the worst that you will deal with from a customer service perspective which impedes on how CSR's handle calls. An overload of racists customers

review_title: Does not value lower level employees
pros: Can be a fun atmosphere, great discount, great product
cons:
corporate and management do not value lower level employees (sales associates) as much as they should. These are the employees that make the sales on a daily basis and generate income for the company; they are often times treated as though they are incompetent to do their job and management looks down on them and you can tell by your interactions with them. 

Write ups for calling out sick when no other employee could/refused cover the shift. Are we in high school? Really??

NO work & life balance, stressed out to go to work , stressed out at work, stressed out after work,  takes a toll on your personal life after awhile.

review_title: Going from start-up to corporation with so much potencial
pros:
Beautiful campus with many great amenities (cafeteria, gym, nutritionist on staff, etc.)
A lot of potencial to make an impact- if you work hard and have the right manager, you can build a career.
Team environment where we support each other and work together.
Leadership really stepped it up for Women’s History month and has done a lot to try to change the culture.
cons:
Pay is not competitive unless you are a manager or above.

We still overhear some Directors make inappropriate jokes. I’ve even seen some bully or act dismissive to female employees trying to put new structure in place or asking questions.

job_title: Sales Associate in Tinton Falls, NJ
pros: I love my coworkers and managers, they're all extremely nice and friendly. The bond we have makes us work together to achieve our sales goals. The employee discount is very nice considering Under Armour clothes are pretty expensive. I always feel happy when I'm at work and often will do overtime just to make some more cash and spend time with fellow teammates. The job is relatively easy, you just inform people of promotions, work the register, and help people find the sizes and colors of what they're looking for.
cons: I've been with the company since May and haven't received any kind of salary increase or promotion despite being an excellent employee that gets great reviews from customers. I'm not authorized to do returns whereas employees who have started working after me have gotten increases in salary and basically the authority of a manager so I'm still confused into how moving up the ladder works around here. Starting Salary was $8.75 an hour which is pretty crummy but the discount makes up for it.

review_title: (Female) Professionals, this Place Isn't Worth your Time
job_title: Senior User Experience/UI Designer in Washington, DC
pros: The campus was a great working environment, with the coffee bar and cafeteria. It was nice to work mostly with people close to my age (20s and 30s), and if you're into fitness it's nice to be in that environment.
cons: Upper management is mainly white male, and be prepared for sons of Kevin Plank's friends to be placed in management positions over qualified employees. The pay is low, the culture has a frat-house feel, and the turnover rate is high. During my time at UA, I experienced several meetings where upper management would scream profanities at members of the team, which seemed to be an accepted part of the culture.

job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Cool store environment. A decent 40% employee discount. Fun if you like interaction with a diverse customer culture. You get trained in extensive product knowledge as an associate.
cons: Cult-like management. They act like camp councilors and treat/talk to the staff like babies. Very controlling over the small things like going on break, and delegating assignments. Certain managers spend the whole day eating long lunches in the office, playing on the computer for hours. Then when they eventually emerge to the sales floor, they are quick to attack a staff member if they don't look constantly busy. The hypocrisy was unreal. The pay is so low, and they force and pressure you to keep wearing and buying the latest UA clothes, that it seems like they are more concerned into making their staff their own customers rather than members. I felt pressured to spend my hard earned money back into the brand to keep up with the UA fashion police.

review_title: Not what you think from the outside
pros:
Fun culture
Company parties 
Great gym
Great colleagues
cons:
Unfortunately this place is a bunch of teenagers playing adults. No one actually knows what they're doing but they run around acting like they do. 

Took many cooks in the kitchen. Everyone is fighting to be the loudest in the room.

Women are not respected as they should be or allowed the same growth paths as their male colleagues. Double standards run rampant. Male is career driven, outspoken, aggressive - great! A woman is, "can you believe how she's acting?". I've seen men act in ways that if a woman ever did the same she would be fired.

HR is TERRIBLE. I can't stress this enough. Nepotism at it's finest. It's shocking what's allowed to fly there.

review_title: Depends who you work for within the company!
pros:
Discount!
Fun atmosphere!
There really are great people there, but pick your friends wisely!
Always thinking outside the box
If you are willing to be a part of the various "clique's" you will advance..join them even if you still do your job to the highest.
HR needs some work...in all areas.
You speak up or stick up for yourself...YOU DIE!
cons:
A LOT of backstabbing.
Most employees are severely underpaid (realized that after I left and see how much more I make now) unless you are a "favorite" or former athlete!
Management team needs a lot of work on managing and how you treat people.
There is no lbalance between work and family unless you are one of the chiefs
Guaranteed bonus?...think twice!

review_title: The most incompetent management team I ever worked with
job_title: Sales Associate in New York, NY
pros: Fun work environment, great customers, great product.
cons:
They hired me in May, It took them over a month to do my paper work which wasted my time. It took weeks of emailing different managers back and forth for them to get it done. I actually found another part time job. Then when they finally completed by profile, they complained that my availability wasn’t good enough because I got another job in the two months that they were taking their sweet time.
Next three months working there were pretty okay, until I came in to work one day (yes I was scheduled ), to find out they took me off the system last minute because i was actually a seasonal worker and the season was over. When I asked why no one told me, they said “someone was supposed to give u a two week notice, but didn’t.. i guess just go home. i’m sorry”.....

pros:
Thrilling brand. The company is currently experiencing explosive growth and there is a lot of room for growth and to harness whatever it is that you want to focus on. 

Baltimore is a cheap and accessible city to live in. A short bus ride away from DC, Philly, and NYC.
cons:
Growing pains of such a company that is growing so fast. Creative process and management are far from being stablished as the environment is rapidly evolving and changing. Expect re-orgs every 6-8 months. 

Baltimore is not a diverse/eclectic city, it's common to meet people who have never left Maryland making the city environment feel a bit under developed not to say ignorant, in a big city context. Not the most exciting city to be a creative and to feel challenged.

pros: Only pro is employee discount
cons:
This place does not reward merit. There are some great leaders on the VP and Director level. But there are also dinosaurs in senior/mid-level management, and a high percentage of dishonest and mean people who hold the company back in terms of terrible culture, product design, consumer connection, incompetence, lack of accountability/effective KPIs, operational disorganization -- . The IT systems are a joke for a company this size -- it's a wonder how any product actually gets out the door without completely angering every wholesaler, supplier, business partner they do business with (and I'm pretty sure they do.. look at how DSG decreased orders and floor space). Terribly disorganized fray and departments don't talk with one another (apparel/accessories and footwear all use different product management systems with a lot of manual Excel work that can be automated). Low pay/comp/benefits. This place is a joke.

Also if you're a minority, don't work here. There's a reason they don't publish their diversity and inclusion stats like literally every other responsible company.

pros: Willing to think outside the box when it comes to technology. Of course the 50% discount is a bonus. Great healthcare at a very reasonable rate compared to what I have paid in the past. Great location at either office (Port Covington or Tide Point).
cons:
Behind in technology, way behind. 
Outsourcing Services seems to be a theme without much thought to what they are getting for what they are paying.

review_title: The place where happiness goes to die
pros: I mean it like paid for rent or something
cons:
Where do I even start?  So every single last person in management you will deal with will want to scream at you in front of all of your coworkers just to assert their authority.  Definitely the antithesis of a place that is healthy.

Leadership has less than zero credibility.  Every single last one of them will lie to you to further their own agenda.  You can't trust a word that is said to you.

Trust that your work will be discarded for no reasons.  Obviously someone has a political agenda and more power to you, that's clearly the only way to achieve a promotion.  Go stab someone in the back, good luck, god speed, I'm sure it will work out for you

This place is fake and toxic.  You can do better.

pros: great company culture, discount, and benefits.
cons: With the company growing at the rate it is, there are many new positions posted. The problem I see is that it is very hard to move up from within. I am well qualified with a degree and years of experience outside the company, and continually overlooked. From my viewpoint it almost feels like you have a better chance moving up, if you leave the company, and apply from the outside. Shame it is like that, but needless to say I am now looking for employment outside. The pay is obviously not up to scale with other companies, but with a great culture some people are willing to accept that. Work/life balance is another issue, but that has been talked about enough.

pros: Great fast-paced culture where everyone drinks the Kool-Aid.  Casual work attire and company parties.
cons: Very low pay for industry standards.  Revolving door of VP's and Executives who come in and change strategy, then leave before being  implemented.  Forced to take on other employees full time positions who are laid off, with no talk or expectation of further compensation.  Make you feel as if you aren't a team player if you don't accept other job responsibilities, in which many cases have nothing to do with what you were hired for initially.  Leadership very detached from the day to day.  Many execs are part of the "boys club" and are rarely seen in office or cascading down strategy or brand initiatives.

review_title: Growing company with plenty of untapped potential!
job_title: Senior Graphic Designer in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Under Armour is a young, fast paced, team oriented company, where hard work is expected, but also well rewarded.

One of our most impactful mantras is to think like an entrepreneur. This gives everyone from top to bottom, the opportunity (and responsibility) to make the company better! This can come in many forms, but speaking from my own experience, I've been allowed to build a team from scratch and define it's structure in, what I believe to be, an innovative way. 

In my 16+ years of corporate work, I can confidently say that I've never seen a culture quite like ours!
cons: Like any young company where things are still being defined, structure and process can be a bit lacking. But those with the drive will find that this is actually a plus, as it gives plenty of opportunity for ownership and the ability to define ones own future.

review_title: Good Employer  with Normal Growth Problems
pros: I enjoyed working for a company that really just wanted to win. It gave employees a lot of autonomy, if they wanted it, to make an impact. While UA isn't a perfect meritocracy they do try to reward greatness through project bonuses and the likes. UA truly has some of the best talent in Baltimore to learn from mixed throughout the company from design to tech. Sometimes you might have to look for it, but it's there I promise you, and those people keep the company going. Finally, the location is great! Right on the water with one of the best views of the Baltimore Inner Harbor
cons: The company grew really quickly so there are quite a few dysfunctional teams to say the least. It's the result of promoting and hiring quickly. To managements credit they are continually adapting, but there definitely is internal turmoil in some teams trying to figure out how to grow with the company.

pros: Unbelievable opportunities at an ever-growing, evolving and game-changing brand that disrupts the marketplace. You'll find that excitement and engagement is always abound and awaiting your input and collaboration no matter your title or seniority. If you love sports and the athletic space you won't find another opportunity like it.
cons: A young company that is getting very big very quickly and maturing alongside a newer more savy sophisticated consumer. Not everything we do is 100% adopted or victorious and there are some growing pains that go along with that.

review_title: Company booming at risk  of losing current talent...
pros: Fast paced and high energy work environment. Young peer group with a lot of potential. Always adding to departments - always growing. Great company parties and excellent product employee discount.
cons: Anyone manager level or below is overworked and underpaid. Company motto is to make one dollar spend like three but for their junior folks, it's really make one person work like three. Very little work/life balance. Perhaps will be worth it long term because of how well the business is doing or, they'll bottom out and lose all their hardworking junior talent and have trouble recruiting in new blood given location. Baltimore is not great and should you break ties with Under Armour, there's no where else to go.

pros: Passionate and motivated teammates working for a common purpose - incredible company culture. Vibrant atmosphere. Makes for a cool day when you go from designing a product to working out in the gym with a UA sponsored athlete!
cons: Extremely poor college recruiting process. Fantastic summer internship program but no follow-up afterwards in regards to full-time offers even though interns were told that they would be contacted.

pros:
- the people where the work gets done are great
-campus
-discount
-international travel
-
cons:
-new senior mangement has made it all about them, not the business or the brand
-horrible communication from top/down
-they have forced out so many long time employees of all levels, that they have lost the culture; just another job now
-company direction is lead now by Finance and HR, which is really challenging around leadership and taking action
-impossible to advance as they make decisions around optics/perception more than performance

pros:
Discount is amazing 
Under Armour is a growing company
cons:
If you want to work for a manager who doesn't follow dress code policy... Or any policy for that matter come to Grapevine
Will chew gum, wear items of clothing outside of the policy but complain or send people home for doing the same 
Store manager is never on the floor and always in the back.. Has other managers give feedback on performance so she doesn't have to
Will write people up for being late, but is NEVER on time herself
Want your time card changed 10-20 minutes just because... Once again Grapevine is the store for you!
Store is always a mess and gets blamed on sales associates, but yet a select few managers don't even know what the standards are. Store manager has been here a year, it has taken a turn for the worse 
The assistant year also been there years, but only does what the SM tells her to do.

review_title: toxic, a terrible place to work
pros: The work was challenging and your direct managers were pretty decent.
cons:
Upper management is extremely dishonest.

So they tell you that Underarmour isn't for everyone when you start... honestly, it's not a place for people with self respect.

If you really loved high school, then this is a place for you.  If you continued to mature after you hit 18, you will be sorely disappointed.

There are managers who love to yell at people in public because they are in a position of power and this is considered normal.  I overheard more than my fair share of screaming matches, it's just part of the corporate culture.  

Management takes one of two approaches, they either avoid you entirely and complain about you behind your back or they turn in to schoolyard bullies.

The pressure to devote your entire life to UA is overwhelming.

pros: If you are under 30 and enjoy a college like atmosphere this is the place for you.  They carry the philosophy work hard play harder so it's usually a good time. However, if you are a professional and expect a somewhat professional environment don't waste your time.
cons: Pay is not competitive. Avoid starting in the call center it is a trap and very few people get out. However, there is an expectation in some departments that you wear certain brands and look a certain way or you won't even be considered.

review_title: The Company Has a Long Way to Go
pros: Company is on a trajectory of growth.  Great potential in the atheltic market.
cons: There is definately a corporate 'boys club'  If you are not one of the boys forget it!  A crushing 'get 'er done' / 'find a way' attitude.  You can't climb the corporate ladder if you are not perceived to be a 'crusher' in the work force.  Asking for help is perceived as failing.  There isn't a strong career path to set employees up for success.  Not enough support given to employees to help them succeed.  Lots of turnover at the Sr. Management positions.  Extremely difficult corporate culture to become part of.  Not inclusive of people who don't fit the perceived mold.  Company preaches innovation but when different ideas are expressed they can be immediately silenced if not what a Sr. Executive wants to hear.

review_title: Not for the faint of heart
pros: I will say that the employees are passionate about the brand and the work they are doing. So much so that most of them moved TO Baltimore to be part of the culture. That's saying something.
cons: They tell you on the first day that "UA is not for everybody." That's 100% accurate. Zero work life balance and total expectations that you must grind your fingers to the bone in order to be successful and progress. Since UA started losing money, the culture has shifted to the point where it's impossible to get anything accomplished with any real allocation of resources. Strategy and goal-setting are so delayed that it feels like most departments are flying blind until deep in the fiscal year.

job_title: Retail Store Manager in Gulfport, MS
pros: Under Armour is an incredible place to work. This company excels when it comes to corporate partnership with the retail field. When employees from the retail field asks, our corporate business partners listen, take action, and follow up to gain better understanding. Like any job, there are obstacles, but with Under Armour there is never a doubt that the company is working diligently to be the best at getting better.  As a retail store manager you own the right to create an engaging culture in your store. You control your four walls and when it come to bonusnpotential the sky is the limit.
cons: No cons. Only boundaries to bend.

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Orlando, FL
pros:
Generous discount
Flexible on scheduling
Comfortable clothing
cons: High turnover on both sales associates and management team. Low pay makes things worse for those who go out of their way and give it their all.  It creates a problem where associates start to not care about their job by either putting in their two weeks notice very quickly or calling out. Sometimes the store becomes a zoo when it is very busy and not enough employees on the floor to support.

review_title: Working at Under Armour was an ok job, there is not much opportunity for employee growth.
pros: Good employee discount of 50%
cons: The managers's are rude, careless, immature, dishonest, and ego-tistic to their employees. The manager's act is if they are better than their associate's. The pay is not that great for the work you do, and the manager's will expect you to work your best. Even when you work your best and ask for employee growth or when you could possibly get a promotion they told me I am far from becoming a manager and I should work harder. Which just can't be true because other manager's go on and on about my hard work. I felt very unpleased to hear my hard work was not apprecitiated.

pros: Great discount with 50% off all merchandise. All Management staff except store manager were great to work with. Employes are tons of fun and energetic.
cons: Spotty schedule, as an associate manager the schedule change so much its hard to have a personal life. Store manager wanted everything herself. Everything is about her and how large bonus can get. Not too much care about our ideas or anything we were excited to share. Store manager had more that 60 people and counting quit in less than one year period because none of them liked her attitude and outlook. No opportunities for growth in move up in management.

job_title: Retail Assistant Manager in Birch Run, MI
pros: If you work hard and do a good job there is potential for career growth as the company opens new stores on a fairly regular basis.  If you are willing to relocate, the potential to move up to store manager is above average compared to other companies.  The pay is somewhat competitive but don't expect to get rich.  They offer a nice benefits package that includes health, dental and vision insurance (as well as vacation time).  This company shows no signs of slowing growth so it is a great time to join the team!
cons: If you are unwilling to relocate, it can become hard to move up in the company due to the fact that many people in management are satisfied with where they are at and new openings don't often happen unless a new store opens up.

review_title: Very supportive leadership, great place to learn
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
The engineering organization is awesome - the leadership is supportive, transparent, and knows what they're doing. The organization uses all kinds of technologies, so there's a ton to learn. Problems range from technical challenges, to people and collaboration challenges, to large architectural challenges. What ever you're looking for, this place will give your career a boost.

A bunch of really cool people - in all 3 of UA's locations. The Austin office is pretty fun, with a startup feel and a healthy and fitness focused attitude. Everyone is super welcoming and helpful.
cons: The business is still learning how to use an engineering organization, and build a product team around software. It acquired some startups and is still working to integrate them to the business. All of this feels pretty normal though, and with the supportive leadership things keep moving forward.

review_title: They don't know what they are doing.  This is a review of Under Armour Corporate.
pros: The gym, the discount, the pay is ok.  Probably a great place to work if you were a male college athlete.
cons:
A horrible place to work if you were not a male college athlete

Have you ever gone jogging in a college neighborhood and accidentally jogged by a frat house?  And all the guys leer and hollar and hoot?  Ok, those guys are all your bosses.  

HR is useless.  If you need to go talk to HR while your there, just get up from your seat, smack yourself in the face, and sit back down.  There, you've saved yourself an hour and a trip down the stairs.  

Long hours.  Inefficiency.  Lots of people leaving and coming.  People are all young and think they are still in college.  It's in Baltimore.

review_title: Great Product, Poor company to work
pros:
-Great product
-Benefits are amazing
-company culture is great if you work in Tide Point, doesn't trickle down to the field
-CEO is determined to catch Nike
cons:
-no work/life balance, managers are expected to work all the times and vacations are only approved once in a blue moon
-there is a lot of talk around people work for people, but this company only cares about the bottom line at the end of the day!

job_title: Assistant Technical Designer in Baltimore, MD
pros: 50% off merchandise is nice, the cafe and cafeteria is awesome, and taking the water taxi everyday to get to work is great!
cons: The office is a little bit like trying to get into a fraternity. People are not always super approachable and everyone is really busy and passionate about what they're doing but if you are an intern or contractor you get no say/very little experience working with a team. The hours are also long and unpredictable. I've known people here who have been at the office all night, gone home to shower, and returned. Doesn't seem to support the healthy lifestyle they seem to be promoting. Also, as a contractor I am required to work full time but they will not give you benefits.

pros: Great teammates and facilities. On campus gym is exceptional. Opportunities for charity work.
cons: Started in IT at UA nearly 5 years ago, and have seen many changes for the worse and a few changes for the best in my tenure.  Our newest CIO brought in an entire new crew from his old company and has turned a hard working scrappy team into a robotic and depressed silos. The teammates are great people, but the leadership leaves much to be desired. When leaders miss timelines or renege on promises there are no consequences.  The company culture changed from that of a startup to a geriatric and slow moving corporation. It's impossible to advance in your career unless you are a part of the "Under Charmer" clique.  UA was a dream job that has slowly turned into a nightmare.

pros:
The campus is great! Gym on the first floor, right on the water, daycare, good + affordable cafeteria, and free parking.
Our team manager is great and coworkers all have different backgrounds and are nice people. Everyone I know truly wants to do well and believes in company.
cons:
IT support is truly the worst at any organization I’ve worked for. They know to give priority to upper management and it takes HOURS to get movement on basic requests. Very poor cost-saving strategy.

Upper managements leadership has been weak and focuses on the basic operations. There’s a lot the company needs to do to address systematic problems with information management. Lots of smart, ambitious people duplicating efforts or Mismanaging their time

pros:
Experience of growing a business
Generally smart people in many departments
Young work culture (comes with its downsides too)
Self-driven environment (flip side of inexperienced managers)
You will enjoy depending on which team you are on and who you are working for (again, not a great advert)
cons:
Company is just beginning to learn the spelling of "diversity" and "inclusiveness"
Many leaders are old school and stale.  little perspective, especially if they have been with the company for 10+ years
Huge culture of favoritism.  (White) boys club mentality.
There are pockets of good teams, but if you work for the wrong team or manager, it can feel like a very different company!
Not the best financial stewardship (for many years now)

pros: Had the pleasure to be apart of some of their biggest campaigns to date, but still always left knowing how great things were getting in the future. They are all passionate and forward thinking while bringing in some of the best minds throughout the industry. With smaller offices, it was great to be able to talk and learn from those who have decades more experience in a stellar environment.
cons: Never settled on a specific vision, which could be a good thing at times, but the constant back and forth in direction left for confusion among team at times.

pros: The Global Headquarters in Baltimore has incredible facilities and campus. Generally speaking, the employees (director and below) are very hardworking and talented.
cons: As an employee, you're constantly reminded of the company's trajectory and it's standing within the pantheon of sporting good companies. You're asked to take personal stake in the company's success and UA does an excellent job encouraging employees to drink the Kool-Aid.  That said, the large majority of employees would acknowledged that you're asked to work longer hours and accept less salary for the "right" to work for UA.  You're made to believe you're hitching your wagon to UA's star and that everyone involved will reap the benefits.  Bad news for all those in the trenches... you'll get nothing and if you don't like it, you'll be replaced.

pros:
The work environment is fast paced and high energy.  This is a young company with room to grow selling a fun and effective product. The culture is overall positive and the majority of the workers mean well and do the best they can (more on this later in the review)

Benefits are good and provide immediate 401k vesting and an employee stock purchase plan.

The buildings and office equipment are all modern and high quality. Occasional free swag, fun work celebration events, and famous athlete coming through. 50% employee discount to all full time employees.  Cafeterias located in both corporate campuses in Baltimore offering very good quality food and selection for okay prices.
 
If you are near the beginning of your career and want experience in a fast paced company this may be a good match

If you don't mind a large amount of process improvement work and challenging the "this is how we've always done it" mantra as a means to grow your career this may be a match.
cons:
There are several things to be aware of before taking a job offer with UA. First is that it is a hyper growth sales company - You will constantly feel reminded of your department's place in the pecking order if you are working in departments classically considered as "Overhead" I.E. Accounting/Finance, HR, Risk Management, IT, Supply Chain. In this company, not surprisingly, Sales, Product, and Marketing reign as top dogs and they reap the rewards of best pay and first dibs at perks. While this is somewhat understandable, management would do well to understand that to hit your lofty growth targets one must seriously consider things like risk and cash management. It wouldn't take much money to invest in some top talent and mangers that are actual vetted professionals in this area. This leads to the next point to be aware of - management.

Many of the managers in this company have worked their way up as the company has grown and no longer have the skills and experience capable to manage in their positions at a company of this magnitude. Most of them mean well, but they just don't have the professional chops and pedigree to manage today's tech savvy analysts. Right now there tends to be more "people management" than "talent management". UA would be wise to invest in some professional management or risk continuing to lose its smartest analytically-minded employees capable of working with enough efficiency to allow the company to reach its growth targets. Show these workers value by paying them their worth.
 
With all that said it does seem that upper management is aware of these challenges stemming from the hyper growth; however, at the moment they just seem to be paying lip service to it. All the needed changes may indeed happen but at this point the company is as described.

UA is the place to work if you love fitness. The office holds a lot of running competitions and events, i.e. a hill run to get test data for a new pair of running shoes, taco runs on Tuesdays. To balance this out, there’s a stocked kitchen with free snacks and drinks. We also get catered lunch on Fridays.

WFH isn’t taboo, thank goodness. There’s also great work-life balance. People come in and leave the office at various times throughout the day to bypass traffic, pick their kids up from school, etc. Work hours are very flexible as long as you get your work done.

My engineering team gets stuff done, and we all want the best for our product. I’m surrounded by smart and humble engineers, and I learn so much every day. We’re not afraid to try new technologies, and that’s pretty neat!

Overall, best office perks are:
- stocked kitchen
- catered lunch on Fridays
- downtown location with close proximity to town lake (if you’re not a runner, you will be after joining UA)
- free classes at local gym
- $50 monthly fitness stipend
- $100 parking stipend per month if you forego your parking pass
- conversely, free parking downtown if you choose to keep your parking pass
- locker room with stocked showers
- free tacos on Tuesday if you go for a run
- fitness-related office events
cons: The free snacks are tough on the waistline. It’s very hard to resist a good peanut butter cup at 3 pm.

review_title: Distribution House, Talks a big game but comes up short

- More overtime than you could possibly imagine.

- Health + Dental benefits after probationary period is completed.

- Incompetent employee's are regularly weeded out.

- Promotion is likely if effort is shown in learning equipment/software.

- The company will occasionally offer lunch, shirts (those with defects), and "armour days" which are usually sporting events free to employees.

- Wages are adequate, with occasional bonuses.
cons:
- A probationary period of 90 days: meaning that you cannot request a day off, lateness is monitored and barely tolerated, no health insurance, also no extra PTO (paid time off) days for working minor holidays.

- 30 minute lunch breaks, tough when you do not bring a packed lunch.

- Working 30-60 days in succession, without a day off is common.

- Multiple departments often need to occupy the same aisles as each other, leading to a general inefficiency in all those involved.

- A computer controlled conveyor system runs throughout the warehouse, which often breaks/stalls which brings all departments to a crawl.

- If working in departments that utilize industrial equipment, be prepared for daily equipment break downs and a general shortage of availability.

- Under Armour has a massive temp employee population working in their distribution house, a edge against layoffs, but most seem unmotivated.

- Communication with non-english speaking temp employees is difficult.

- Safety equipment is generally adequate, but condition is generally awful.

- There is no heating/AC in the warehouse.

- Parking is a minor issue.

- Bathrooms are just awful.

review_title: Enjoy the discount, the fun - dread the logistics
pros: Great employee discount and dress code - you get to wear what you sell!  Fun atmosphere as if you're into exercise and sports you'll meet a lot of like-minded people.
cons: Considering the brand is so hot, and my store exceeded plan every quarter - I was rewarded with a 1% raise because "times are tough".  The Corporate side gets every perk - cafeteria, movie nights, baseball games etc, while the retail stores can't even get $100 for an xmas party or some employee recognition.  Horrific turnover due to the regionals lowballing managers so they only get the least qualified or most desperate.  Regionals coming to a hot brand from failed brands only lead to terrible ideas and poor execution.  Logistics are a nightmare -easily expect for more freight than your store can possibly handle, leading to dozens of boxes stored in external pods - and not having the hours to staff your store in any semblance of competancy. No replenishment model - sell 100 of one shoe, get 100 of a shirt you can't sell for anything.  They only see units, not skus - and don't discount the stuff they have surplus of...  Under Armour retails stores are outlets - not front line retailers...and they try to run them like boutiques - which is even further from the model they actually are.  The POS/Operating system is a joke as well - way too many bugs and a call center in India.  Work there for the discount and atmosphere, just don't expect to go far or make it long....anyone who's been in retail will see they just don't have a handle on what they're doing yet.

I have worked for the company for almost 5 years and decided to part ways because upper management does not value good workers. They treat staff as though everyone is replaceable, regardless of efforts or success in completing tasks.

The Sr. ASM role is one level below store manager, so it is to be expected that there is a lot of responsibility, however, DM’s do not hold store managers accountable (at least in my district)  so you end up doing more work than the store manager while getting paid much less. 

The pay bands are unreasonable, especially for sales associates. The freight position is typically an overnight position but they still get paid the same as floor sales associates.

The DM acts like a robot, per se, and shows no sympathy or support for their other managers besides store manager. Lastly, since the DM consistently has their store manager’s back (which is fine), the store manager is also never held accountable - mostly sits in the office as though it were a desk job rather than retail, pawns off tasks on the rest of the management staff as they say they have more important things to do, and hasn’t had a single developmental conversation with me to help me improve upon my leadership skills. 

The HR department is very difficult to deal with and rarely allows the retail team to hold employees accountable for call outs or misconduct, without questioning the manager attempting to initiate the corrective action. This results in the team thinking it’s okay to call out without coverage, or not show up at all. 

Finally, the staff I have worked with both previously and presently are often very young (typically 18-20) meaning there is constantly drama and rumors which makes the environment very toxic and difficult to work in. I have worked at 4 different stores, all of which were the same situation. 

UA is a very operationally focused company that puts more value in processing freight efficiently instead of stressing importance of the wellbeing of teammates.

I have no bad blood with this company, and I did enjoy working at UA initially but unfortunately, things change, policies change, and I just don’t see the need to give 110% effort to a place that considers you easily replaceable.

review_title: Awesome Work Place - Little to None Growth Opportunities
pros: Happy and positive people everywhere! Massive cafeteria. Endless events. Monthly opportunities to meet professional athletes. Educational courses. Bike around the campus. Amazing benefits including tuition reimbursement but only for full-time employees. Discounts from local businesses such as Smoothie King or Charm City Yoga. Awesome break areas that include cornhole, XBOX, televisions, basket ball court, and so much more. 50% off UA apparel.  50% off UA gym memership. Amazing support system. Each department is considered a team and you are considered a team member. Company contests to win cool prizes. Armour Day which features celebrities and a surprise music group performance such as One Republic, Nelly, Kid Rock, and many others. I met Ed Reed and touched the lead singer of One Republic. Team members are the first to see and sometimes purchase new gear. Very flexible schedule. A lot of diversity.
cons: Little opportunity for growth within the company. Although the company's policy allows for employees who are part-time to commit at least 6 months, 1 year for full-time employees, before they can seek other opportunities within the company. In reality, it takes about 2 years of commitment to your current position and the say-so of your manager before you can move to a different position or department. In a lot of cases, employees were offered other roles in the company but were forced to turn back simply because the job wasn't there or the need in their previous department was not met. A lot of cliques of sorts. The designers have their own people, engineers have their group, team management has theirs, and the e-commerce department can also be split. As a part-time representative, you have to work just as hard as a full-time employee in order to meet sales and customer interaction goals. You also don't qualify for weekly or monthly contest unless you put in the same work as a full time employee. Putting in the work would include making 2x more calls than the ideal 9am-3pm employee would. Felt like a target of harsh criticism by another employee (who wasn't management) for my performance.

cons: As with any job, there can be managers who no one really likes. At my store there's only one, but everyone else is really awesome.

review_title: Unfair and lacking diversity on the corporate level
pros:
A great place to meet good people 
The overall atmosphere of the company is good
Good as a brand, not as a company (business)
cons:
Extremely lacking in racial diversity
Lacks adequate training for persons promoted to managerial positions 
Favortism is rampant 
Non-supportive of persons in roles outside of management 
Clique mentality runs rampant

review_title: UA has been a very rewarding experience with a steep learning curve.
pros: The culture at UA is by far the best thing about the company. It's fast paced and young. We are on the brink of greatness and that's very exciting.
cons: UA is a small company with a big name. We have a need for better processes and systems. Need a taining  program to support our younger employees.

pros: I enjoy working at Under Armour because of the strong sense of team across the entire organization. People actually help each other succeed.  I also enjoy the fast-paced nature of  decision-making at UA including a willingness to acknowledge ineffective decisions and to quickly change to correct.
cons: If you can't handle change and a fast paced environment, Under Armour is not the place for you.

pros: Nice environment, beautiful office, free gym, fun colleagues (who are either overworked or not doing anything all day)
cons: Everything else. Very high turnover, toxic teams, management is incapable of taking logical decisions, rule by fear, people are promoted based on likability, no career opportunities unless you are part of the elite group.

review_title: Unorganized work environment.  Favoritism and Gossip
pros: down to earth peers and company events are awesome!
cons: People are promoted not on their skills but if they are someone's friend or in the cool crowd.  Some departments are all gossip and is not professional.  Not a healthy environment.

review_title: The experience there was horrible. We had a manager who hated his job and an assistant manager who disliked everyone.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Marcos, TX
pros: Everyone employed with Under Armour received a 50% discount off of everything which was nice. Everyone who was non-management was friendly and laid back.
cons: Too many rules to follow. You pretty much have annoy the customer the whole time they are there giving them information about everything they are looking at and how the product is the best. You have to strike up conversation with every customer that comes in. JUST LET THEM SHOP!

pros:
-50% discount on merchandise
-$9 per hour
cons:
-Schedule
-Force you to sell to customers
-Overbearing

pros: There are no limits! If you can dream it then you can make it happen at UA. I've had the opportunity to work on things I never had the chance to be part of at larger/older organizations. I love the high energy and the constant challenges.
cons: It's an ever changing and evolving organization. Some people don't thrive in that type of environment. You truly have to love and care about the success of the company.

pros: Ability to have a healthy lifestyle/fitness be integrated with your daily work routine.
cons: The treatment of employees is not great. The company lacks direction and the ability to honestly look into what needs to change. Design teams are very outdated. There are people who are hard workers and are always looking how to do something better, but the vast majority are the people who are content with status quo. The product design truly reflects this. Also, too many layers in management and not enough people to do the actual work. Very top heavy.

pros: Under Armour has a pulse like no other company.  In general, co-workers, attitude and passion were amazing.
cons: Upper Management is poor in some areas.  Upper management did not care about Junior level employees.  Junior level employees were a dime a dozen to upper management.  Turn over rate was extremely high.  Junior employees would work for a year and move on to bigger pay checks.  Even employees that had been there for years were treated as disposable.

review_title: Good company to work for, but they haven't quite figured out the logistics aspects yet
pros: Great employee discount, great team work environment, great employee stock purchase program after probationary period. The company has great sales associates and store managers but lacks in the regional and upper management area. The company does have very strong values towards their customers and producing quality products.
cons: Logistics of transport and sales promotions seem to have zero reasoning behind what happens. Zero effective changes are put in place, when the associates and store managers highlight something thats wrong.

pros: Love working for this company! The benefits and discounts awesome!
cons: Retail store managers don't know how to communicate with employees or their other management. Retail side doesn't really allow you to have a life outside of work with schedules always changing week to week.

pros: Great brand. Growing rapidly. Fully invested CEO. Ability to move forward with company. Great benefits stock options and discounts.
cons: No work life balance. Higher than achievable expectations many times. Not enough structure and directions for rate of growth. If you are not willing to come in on days off work over 45 hours a week and give up every weekend not the best place to work.

job_title: Sales Associate in Wisconsin Dells, WI
pros: the company offers a great discount, which is a very big plus side to working there. there is also a great environment whenever i work, which makes it all the better.
cons: the pay isnt really that great, i have been looking at other jobs to pay for bills and such. can not use discount on all things, which is sometimes a bummer.

review_title: Biggest small company of the world
pros: Under Armour has great benefits, best-in-class work atmosphere and is one of the up and coming brands in the world. There are plenty of opportunities to grow within the organization and being relocated to different places
cons: Work life balance is terrible. The business grew way faster than the infrastructure of the organization, so it's not only understaffed but severely affected by lack of tools to get stuff done.

pros: Huge discount on product, both online and in store. Decent health care plans, stock options, Personal Time Off.
cons: Repetitive work. Long hours. You don't always get off for holidays.

pros: Great Brand with Excellent leadership at Tide Point.  They offer a great discount for amazing product as well as a good compensation package (they could be more competitive with pay).
cons: No advancement opportunities for management.  The staffing levels in the stores are minimal at best with all they expect to be accomplished.  They consistently want the best talent but are unwilling to pay for it.

pros: You can pick up a lot of extra hours when it is busy which is always a plus in my opinion.
cons: Because I did not have a voided check with me during my interview(I was never asked to bring one) it was very difficult to set up direct deposit. I had to be paid by a preloaded debit card that had a lot of fees.

pros: Good only for temporary work. You get a fifty percent discount if you're hired on. That's basically it, nothing else.
cons: Long hours. Terrible pay. Hot environment. I could go on and on but I'm pretty sure you don't want to read forever.

pros: Great product with an awesome discount. Lots of fun working within the store with travel and growth opportunities. Great benefits.
cons: Short staffed on management. Have had people ready to move into positions for almost half a year with no push from upper Managment. No work life balance. Heavy workloads without hours support. Lots of disorganization with upper management and difficulties getting support from dms and other stores. Policies and procedures change several times a month as the company continues to grow and management does not know how to handle it.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Baltimore, MD
pros: Fantastic employee parties.  Good people.
cons: Low pay... buddy buddy system, only hire friends.   No one is actually qualified.  Will pass up on employees whose resume read the position for getting their bros in.  Will work you to death for nothing that helps you.

review_title: The UA recipe: hire young ambitious people, overwork them/underpay them, move on to the next person once they burnout.
pros: Healthcare benefits, merchandise discount, nice facilities, good job experience
cons: Leadership is constantly changing and very distant, no work/life balance, shareholders constantly put before employees

pros:
- UA has a Great employee discount for yourself or to purchase as gifts
- Generally really nice people at headquarters
- Opportunity to demonstrate value by going above and beyond
cons:
- Senior Management consists of a lot of the founder's friends that may not necessarily have the qualifications and experience required to excel in those particular roles 
- Can be very long work hours
- Baltimore as a city isn't for everyone

pros: The benefits are really good and you get most holiday's off if you work at corporate.
cons: Not a great work/ life balance, they expect you to work around the clock and support multiple people

pros: The company has a lot of potential due to its rapid growth; there's a lot more to look forward to in the future. It promotes its employees to strive for a more creative and innovative way of thinking.
cons: As a company expanding rapidly, it may be challenging to adapt to the company's pace. However, this pushes us to think differently and results in a more innovative ideology.

job_title: Team Lead in Curtis Bay, MD
pros: Cheap Benefits, 50% Discount on all Under Armour Products, 401k match, Employee Stock Purchase Plan, Plenty of room to move up, job stability
cons: Pay is slightly lower than other warehouse work, Long hours (12 hour shifts), often work holidays

review_title: Bully Corporation coupled with leaders that are promoted well beyond their capability
pros: Great discounts (that's a plus especially since quality "UGOP" is still an opportunity) for UA!
cons: Bully corporation - the "leaders" are quick to subscribe to group think and all target the demise of one another.

job_title: Marketing Operations Specialist in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: The people are great, the culture and the experience you acquire is amazing.  You are free to try out new stuff and make changes.
cons: I think it is complicated to migrate from Local to Region or Global. Pay gap between countries and regions is enormous. there is no chance to renegotiate salary.

pros:
Growth- we're just recently established in footwear international, women's
Teammate Energy - our teammates have love for the brand and the people they work with.  We can do anything!
We work in the business of sports!
Flexibility - we value and serve the communities where we work.  
Professional Growth - lots of change leads to lots of new experiences.
cons: Nothing stays the same.  Be prepared, when you get comfortable with something or somebody it will change.

pros: Hands down finest employee discount program that exists. Amazing product at glorious prices.
cons:
Not that all managers are terrible, this one was. I know she has since been terminated. I was grossly under utilized - I had an MBA working front line retail. The hours became very burdensome - often until 6 am or coming in at 3 am. 

"Teammates" are not sales people. They are merchandise processors and navigators.

pros: company on the rise, innovative technologies, fun environment, athletic feel.  The atmosphere is fast-paced, and suits athletes/gym-goers well.
cons: Must have the ability to move around quickly, and meet strict deadlines.  Deadlines include daily and hourly tasks.  You may often experience times where your location is understaffed, and must accommodate regardless.

pros: The biggest pro of working at Under Armour is the discount...50% is very generous! Plus you get to use it on sale and clearance items as well. Management is usually handled very professionally. Day to day operations (shifts) are lighthearted and fun with an emphasis on customer service and inventory management.
cons: Not very much room to grow in the company. Jobs are not focused enough on meeting sales goals. Below average pay.

pros: Excellent company to work for, amazing Sales Meetings, one of the fastest growing companies in the world, and a great product.
cons: Lack of communication from high up management down the latter.  Very little training before you are sent out to see accounts.

review_title: Really make sure before you decide to work for UA
pros: Great sales employees. Amazing assistant managers.
cons: Lack of communication amongst the management (especially the store manager), lack on appropriate training for associates,  lack of compassion, hours and availability.

pros:
Opportunity! Growth! The privilege to work in sport!
Lots of chances to make an impact and a difference in a young $5B company with a Vision.
cons: Due to the fast paced nature of a growth company in a ever-changing industry landscape --those who do not handle change well will not enjoy this environment.

job_title: Sales Associate in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great atmosphere, great discount on awesome clothes. Some managers are really cool and understanding of second jobs, school, etc. No uniform just wear UA and you're all good!
cons: Not enough pay. No benefits for part-time associates. Some managers just chill and do nothing while others are working way too much, causing stress that ends up getting passed down to employees. Serious lack of career opportunities despite what company says.

job_title: Senior Team Lead in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great benefits.  You get most major holidays off.  Job security is there.  Yearly bonuses are decent. The team is pretty diverse.
cons: The teammate moral is pretty low.  A lot of people are overworked and/or do a lot out of their job descriptions without compensation.  Not a lot of room for growth.

pros: I've worked for many retail companies, and Under Armour by far surpasses the rest. When it comes to hiring there isn't a specific image a candidate has to be. The companies goal is to improve athletes everywhere. Anyone can be an athlete, whether they're trying to live a healthier life for their kids, or have an upcoming game.
cons: I think their store atmosphere could improve. Their music selection doesn't update. There are no part-time employee benefits

review_title: GMs and DMs can be awful
pros: Most of your teammates make it less painful when you work.
cons: General managers (at least the two that ran my location) were awful. Disrespectful and made lewd comments to female workers. Showed up when they wanted and left when they wanted cause they’re salaried. My GMs were very close to the DM so you could never count on anything being done if you wanted to submit a complaint when it came to the vulgarity and toxicity of the work environment.

pros: 50% discount on everything including online purchases, work uniform was to wear Under Armour so it was comfortable
cons: You are required to wear Under Armour but are expected to buy the outfits, was hard to make any money at all at first when it was all being spent on what was required to wear to work

pros: Enthusiastic workers.  Iconic Brand.  Employee discounts on all products.
cons: High Turnover rate in upper management means the company reorganizes itself at least once a year.  It also means lack of consistency in priorities and goals.  Senior leaders like to micro-manage.  Frequent hiring freezes to achieve budget goals means you must pick up extra work when a co-worker leaves.  However, these freezes do not limit the number of senior leaders who will be hired.

review_title: Great job with a great brand
pros: Fast-paced, challenging environment where we are given the freedom to grow within our role and encouraged to look for new ways to support our team and brand.
cons: Exponential growth of the company has created some communication challenges.

review_title: Young company with lofty goals, but, has the talent and firepower to accomplish them.
job_title: Sales Specialist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: This company is not afraid to think outside the box and is willing to change with the birth of new ideas.
cons: Employees become very loyal to the company, but the company is not as loyal to employees. Sales associates and Store managers become expendable.

job_title: Seasonal Sales Associate in San Clemente, CA
pros: It was a relatively easy first job. I had a great time going into work. Sometimes, it would get boring but overall good experience. Good seasonal summer job.
cons: There work schedule was random and I didn't have set days to which I work which was difficult to create time to have a personal life

review_title: A challenging world ... if you like that kind of stuff.
pros: You like to build stuff ? You want ownership and responsibility ? You up for a challenge? This is the place.  Keeps you on your toes, makes you find innovative solutions, forces you to work with others. Inclusive and diverse.
cons: Still in start-up mode. Fail-fast approach still holds true. Not a lot of advanced technical talent. (but that could be a pro, for you)

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Oshkosh, WI
pros: During college I worked part time as a sales associate for Under Armour. They were very willing to work with my school schedule, the atmosphere was fun and energetic. I worked at one of there outlet stores and we received 50% off merchandise.
cons: If you aren't outgoing and love interaction, this might not be the job for you. They stress interacting with every single person who walks in the door. I loved it, but it might not be for everyone.

job_title: Store Lead in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Awesome work environment, flexible hours, amazing co workers, 50% discount on everything, Staff dress is just anything Underarmour.
cons: Hours are a joke if you go into a brand house store, they take their time when trying to promote, the company doesn't give you an outfit to start out, they make you buy clothes before your first day.

job_title: DH Operations Manager in Curtis Bay, MD
pros: The Team at the DH do there best to work together to achieve their daily goals. The Benefits are bar none better then any other distribution warehouse in maryland
cons: The Disconnect between the DH and the Tide Point  Headquarters are paramount including the way the "teams " are treated between the production warehouses as well as the goals of the company.

pros: Lots of white space. Opportunity to grow and make an impact. Tons of areas to make the company better. Proactive and intellectually curious people are very successful.
cons: Change is constant. Structure lacks in certain areas. Leaders could be more transparent and communicative at times. Could get better at planning, especially around people.

pros: The energy and team is incredible. I'm always impressed by the hard work of the teammates and their enthusiasm for success. It is a great, results and operation driven culture that drives self-improvement and team engagement.
cons: The company askes for much, but gives little. The compensation for the workload is meager, and industry-low, while the expectations are high with little company oversight. The employees are treated as expendable and undeserving, while being asked to "be better."

job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Awesome benefits with discounts on rental cars, phone service, child care, etc...
Hand picking the team you have working under you makes for a true "team" feel.
cons:
Unclear/lack of communication from top down
No work/life balance for salaried employees
Inconsistent messaging between RMs and DMs make it impossible for store teams to please anyone higher up...

job_title: O Real Cons Tp Mention Other Than the Compant IS in Nashville, TN
pros: Its a great place to work. I would recommend this company to anyone looking for a great job with great advancement opportunity
cons: no real cons to mention except maybe the company is based in Baltimore and some of management tend to think that is how all of the locations should be run.

Physical workplace
Fellow new Associates
Easy to get hired permanently

review_title: Great people, great mission, great place to work.

pros: This company gives pretty decent pay. It's a fun and beautiful environment to work in. The people are really nice as well.
cons: I don't really have anything I dislike about the company. I find it a really enjoyable place for anyone who wants to build a graphic design portfolio.

review_title: Great environment, great managers, terrible pay.
pros: You will always have fun with the other employees, and the discount's great. You have a chance to gain experience in all parts of retail, such as: stock, sales, and shoes.
cons: The pay is not the greatest. You don't always get many opportunities to move up the chains. It never seems like your hard work is noticed.

review_title: Good pay but no room to grow with company
job_title: Selling Specialist in New York, NY

pros: They have a great manager staff with amazing benefits of clothing prices. They also have the option for a 401k and health care plans, although I did not partake in those.
cons: The company doesn't run nearly as smoothly as competitors such as Nike. They use outdated processes that are more time consuming, thus more costly.

pros: Great products, facilities and location. Peers were great to work with. Not much job structure, which was a good thing for me.
cons: The management is very disorganized. I truly think the main issue is lack of experience. The company grew very quickly and most of upper-management had their first job here and just stayed.

pros: company is always growing , the company holds bright future , job security , fairness , respect , great products , employee discount
cons: it can be a lot to handle during holiday season , some people believe it is too fast pace , allocation for shipment , not having enough hangers at times

pros: Great benefits, great culture, great growth opportunity, most management is very family conscious and as long as you're getting your job done on a daily basis... you can come and go as needed, great vacation benefits
cons: Do the job of 5 people but one salary, will not get paid what you deserve unless you fight for it, SVP's have a VERY big say in the day to day business

pros: The discount is fantastic [half off], and the benefits package for full time employees is unbelievable.
cons: Toxic work place environment, and poorly structured corporate sector. Salary is NOT competitive, in any way. I average 58 hours per week, and make marginally more than my other managers.

pros: Strong ability to advance quickly. However, personality counts more than technical ability. Praise all processes and make the management team feel competent and you'll be successful.

job_title: Associate Manager in San Marcos, TX

pros: Excellent opportunity for candidates with little experience to move up in company as long as they display a great work ethic.

review_title: Low on the pay scale, high on job satisfaction and incentives
job_title: Account Marketing Manager in Baltimore, MD

cons: Slightly underpaid however can you put a dollar amount on job satisfaction?

pros: Great company to work for with lots of room for upward mobility.  Looking forward to building my career with such a great brand.

job_title: Cashier Specialist in Kansas City, KS

pros: Decent pay, incredible discount, and an opportunity to learn about new products before they hit the shelves. A fine job as far as retail is concerned.
cons: The same cons that go for any retail job - you will probably have to perform mindless, tedious work in between time actually spent with customers.

pros: great experience and there was great product. Cool people to work with. Great discount. The environment was good for a first time job.

pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Under Armour: the employee discount, the great work environment and all of the other employees are awesome.
cons: Some of the downsides for working at Under Armour include the high prices of the products and you must be clothed in all of their products.

job_title: Sports Marketing Customer Service Representative in Baltimore, MD
pros: Started as a part-time employee at a factory house during college. I was selected as a summer rookie - Great program, learned all I could about UA, loved it and UA loved me. Finished my Master's and UA hired me for a full time position. Low salary, but I relocated, loved the job, loved Baltimore, loved most of the people I worked with & still keep in touch with them! Great location, healthy environment with discounted gym membership, fun corporate events and 50% discount on UA product.
cons: I was encouraged and complimented on my work (also told I was leader among my peers in my end of year review). I was also invited to travel with Sales Managers to multiple accounts later throughout the year... only to be "let go" just before I was there 1 year (just before raise and bonus time, hmmm) Weeks later, I found out this happened to about 20-30 others but was kept very quiet to those still employed at UA...  still unsure how they got away with it but had I come from a wealthier family, I would have without a doubt hired a lawyer to investigate further. Months later, I was replaced and did some investigative work to find out that my "replacement" is making even less than I was... so basically letting a bunch of us go, to re-hire someone for less was a great way to save some money... but I find it very unethical.

pros: Exciting, energetic, fun at times.
cons: People get let go and not replaced, shifting work to already overworked staff.  New executives bring in their own people instead of opportunities being available to existing staff.  Lots of high priced executives have been brought in, they make big org changes and are gone within a few years.  High turnover at the VP, SVP level impacts everyone in the organization below.

pros:
Flexible Schedule and easy to take time off
Discount is great and makes it much easier to buy in store

cons: It can be difficult at times to balance school and work especially working closing shifts,  but that is expected in any retail positions. Can be difficult to get time off sometimes because of company policy.

pros: great team vibe and high energy work place. Everyone is very competitive in a good way and those that succeed are those that go the extra mile. It is very entrepreneurial in spirit which mean you can essentially own your business and push the envelope.
cons: it's a hard place if your not used to the hustle and craziness. Those that don't fit the mold do not typically last.

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Kittery, ME

pros: Very easy job. Just talk to customers, ring them up, and clean up the store. The managers are great and love to talk and hear suggestions. If the pay was better I would still work there, but you get a great discount on the merchandise.
cons: Low pay and sometimes scheduling can be a grueling task. They have a lot of staff so getting all the hours you want can be difficult.

pros: The campus is really nice and on the harbor, they're even expanding to make it even bigger and nicer. Most of the employees are super talented and work very hard. There's also a really nice discount on product. The three days of training were fun.

While most of the employees are very talented and hard working, the managers and directors are not. Managers and directors come in to work hours after everyone else and leave earlier than everyone while they pile work onto others. The hours many people end up working are 7am to anywhere from 7-11pm. Managers and directors will only come into the office 1-3 times a week which leads to a lot of communication problems and errors. At the same time, projects are always missing deadlines unless people stay until 3 or 4am to get things done. The managers and directors are aware of these problems, but aren't doing anything to make the process more time efficient. 

The company is also expanding at such a fast rate that there's a lack of organization and space for everyone. One person didn't have a desk when they started and had to work in the kitchen for a few months. Other times teams will be completely separated from each other which only makes the communication problems worse. 

When I started the training process they really stressed how important the companies values were and how the work culture here is great. But this ended up being one of the most unprofessional and juvenile places I ever worked. People were openly mocked for their health condition by directors and were ridiculed and rumored about to other employees. It seemed to be a great place if you participate in the extreme sucking up to directors, but if you place your priorities on working hard at your job, you would be treated hostilely. Other people were moved or reassigned to new teams and not even told by management about the change.
